# 總裁報告

2016年的全球政經舞台上「黑天鵝」身影頻仍，英國脫歐公投和美國總統大選結果固然令各種民調淪為笑柄，但更出乎意料的卻是金融市場的反應。以美國大選為例，特朗普當選消息令美股三大指數的期貨在開市前急挫，但開市不久美股指數隨即反彈，此後凱歌高奏，屢創新高。連串事件，凸顯了傳統智慧和思維對預測市場能力的局限性，也標誌着未來環球局勢發展的重大不確定性。

過去一年，多項主要金融數據都反映市場情緒異常敏感：美國十年期國庫債券收益率在7月跌至1.36厘歷史低位後，在美國總統大選後的12月中旬飆升至2.6厘。反映美元兌一籃子貨幣走勢的美匯指數在年底升至14年高位；紐約原油期貨價格由年初每桶26美元低位反彈至年底的54美元。本港股市方面，恒生指數全年微升86點，但期內峰谷差逾6,000點。外圍形勢驚濤駭浪，更形金融體系尤其是貨幣和銀行體系穩定的重要和可貴。

2016年1月，國際對沖基金部署狙擊人民幣和港元的傳言甚囂塵上，人心虛怯。金管局迅即向市場發放明確、堅定的訊息，我們絕對有信心、有能力捍衛聯匯制度和香港的金融體系穩定，適時穩住了市場信心。綜觀2016年全年，港元長時間貼近強方兌換保證。由於銀行體系資金非常充裕，即使去年12月和今年3月美國聯儲局加息，對港元利率和匯率並未有明顯的即時影響。

香港銀行體系繼續穩步發展，去年整體貸款錄得6.5%溫和增長，資產質素保持良好，不良貸款比率維持在0.85%的健康水平，遠低於2000年以來約2%的長期平均水平。銀行體系的資本充足率和流動性比率均保持在高於法定要求的高水平。在樓宇按揭業務方面，經過七輪逆周期措施，新造住宅物業按揭平均成數從2009年9月的64%下降至2016年底的51%，平均供款與入息比率也從2010年8月的41%下降至2016年底的34%，為樓市周期一旦逆轉而令銀行體系受到衝擊時，提供了所需的緩衝。金管局會繼續密切留意樓市的發展，因應周期變化而採取合適措施，以保持銀行體系穩定。

進一步強化銀行體系穩定的立法工作去年取得令人鼓舞的進展。優化存款保障制度和針對金融機構「大得不能倒」風險的兩條法例，及時在上屆立法會任期屆滿前順利通過。前者加快存款保障金的發放速度，簡化發放程序，有助加強存戶對銀行體系的信心；後者則為包括銀行在內的金融機構建立處置機制，防範這些機構一旦倒閉而引發的系統性金融風險，並盡量避免動用公帑為它們「包底埋單」。金管局已在今年4月1日設立處置機制辦公室，落實執行法例的要求和跟進工作。

銀行業素有「百業之母」之稱，是實體經濟和普羅市民日常生活倚重的儲蓄、支付渠道和信貸來源。年內，部分中小企業界代表反映融資有困難。金管局即時與銀行界溝通，希望銀行在維持審慎風險管理的情況下，盡可能為中小企的營運和發展繼續提供資金支援。我們又透過轄下香港按揭證券公司，加強向工商界推廣政府的「中小企融資擔保計劃」，並與銀行業界緊密溝通，以釋除疑慮、釐清誤解及理順處理壞帳的索償程序，從而提高銀行參與該計劃的意願。多管齊下，收到了一定成效，根據金管局對銀行進行的調查，中小企整體信貸額度在去年保持平穩，超過九成企業的信貸額度得以維持甚至增加。同時，「中小企融資擔保計劃」的申請數字亦明顯上升。

近年來金管局大力推動普及金融，就是考慮到基本銀行服務已是營商和日常生活不可或缺的環節。去年當我們得知有些海外公司和初創企業在香港開戶遇到困難後，旋即展開跟進工作，與多個國際商會和企業協會聯繫，並跟銀行業界深入溝通，對症下藥。去年9月我向香港所有銀行簽發通告，闡釋應如何理解金管局針對反洗錢和恐怖分子資金籌集活動的「風險為本」監管原則，如何將這項原則應用在開戶申請和對現有客戶的盡職審查措施上，強調銀行不應對所有客戶採用「一刀切」的要求和程序。經我們與銀行和商界協商後，企業開戶情況有所改善，但仍有進步空間，這也是我們今年工作重點之一。

普及金融還涉及銀行分行服務的覆蓋面。金管局一直鼓勵銀行在營商圖利之餘，也要顧及市民的基本銀行服務需要。金融科技一日千里，銀行提供服務的渠道也更趨多元化。除了日益普及的網上銀行服務外，去年多家銀行紛紛推出流動銀行車或視像櫃員機服務，提供較傳統櫃員機更貼身、更全面的銀行服務。在我們的推動下，多家銀行也計劃在偏遠地區設立實體分行，加強對當區居民的服務。

金融中心的發展就如逆水行舟，因此，金管局多年來不斷為香港金融業發展尋求新的契機，開拓新的領域。2016年可說是成果豐碩的一年，當中又以金融科技(Fintech)和基建融資為亮點。

在金融科技方面，香港的零售支付服務在2016年進入新時代。金管局去年發出13個儲值支付工具牌照，通過發牌和恒常監管制度為零售支付服務創造有利的營商環境，配以一系列公眾教育宣傳，讓消費者在享受新科技帶來的便捷之餘，權益也得到合理保障。

此外，去年3月金管局成立了金融科技促進辦公室，以此平台推動與銀行業相關的金融科技發展。幾個月間，我們推出多項新猷，包括「網絡防衛計劃」(Cybersecurity Fortification Initiative)，為強化銀行體系網絡安全建立風險評估、資訊共享和人才培訓三足鼎立的新平台。我們並與香港應用科技研究院（應科院）合作，開展分布式分類帳技術(distributed ledger technology)專項研究，探討該技術在香港銀行業應用的可行性，並在應科院設立金融科技創新中心(Fintech Innovation Hub)，為銀行業界和金融科技界提供技術支援。金管局的銀行監管部門還設立「金融科技監管沙盒」(Fintech Supervisory Sandbox)，讓銀行在較小和可控範圍內測試新技術的應用，為新產品、新服務的開發提速。自去年9月至今年3月，已有6家銀行共14項新技術項目使用沙盒進行測試，部分項目亦已相繼推出市場，為市民帶來更多金融科技的新產品。

世界各地對基建融資的需求巨大，特別是「一帶一路」倡議提出以來，基建融資更成中外矚目的議題。香港是亞洲的國際金融中心，在基建融資領域極具優勢。去年7月金管局成立了基建融資促進辦公室(Infrastructure Financing Facilitation Office，簡稱IFFO)，搭建一個嶄新和獨特的平台，匯聚60多家世界級的多邊機構、機構投資者、銀行、保險公司和其他金融機構、基建項目的建設和營運方、各類專業機構等，就基建投融資課題互通訊息、交流經驗、尋求合作機會。IFFO成立至今已舉辦十多場大型會議、研討會和工作坊，金管局並分別與國際金融公司(International Finance Corporation)、全球基礎設施中心(Global Infrastructure Hub)、國家開發銀行(China Development Bank)和中國進出口銀行(The Export-Import Bank of China)簽署了共同促進基建投融資活動的《諒解備忘錄》。起步時間雖然不長，但為香港未來作為基建投融資中心奠下堅實的基礎。

拆牆鬆綁是提升競爭力的不二法門。年內，金管局積極參與和支援特區政府修訂稅務條例，向在港經營集團內部財資業務的企業提供有利的稅務環境。我們並積極接觸跨國企業，吸引它們來港發展或擴充企業財資活動，藉此進一步強化香港金融市場的功能。

去年的離岸人民幣市場處於調整期。受市場波動和對人民幣匯率預期等因素影響，全球離岸人民幣資金池規模普遍收縮。儘管如此，香港仍穩執離岸人民幣業務的牛耳，保持全球最大的人民幣資金池，經香港結算的人民幣維持在日均約8,600億元人民幣高位。為進一步優化香港離岸人民幣市場的流動性安排，去年10月我們將一級流動性提供行由7家增至9家，支援雙邊流動資金的總額度由原來的140億元人民幣增至180億元，確保在離岸人民幣市場資金出現緊絀的情況下，仍可保持市場有序運作。去年12月股票市場「深港通」開通，令香港的人民幣業務再添動力。金管局亦正與內地有關當局研究「債券通」方案，進一步便利兩地投資者參與債券市場，並優化債券市場基礎設施的聯繫。

儘管去年全球投資環境充斥着各種不穩因素，但有賴於過去一段時間所採取的多項防禦性部署，外匯基金去年錄得681億港元投資收入。自1994年以來外匯基金的複合年度投資回報率達4.8%，高於同期2.1%的本地通脹率。

外匯基金將繼續推動多元化投資，包括進一步擴展資產類別，加大對於信貸資產、抵禦通脹類投資產品和新興市場的投資。而作為多元化投資旗艦的「長期增長組合」，透過私募股權和房地產項目等投資於另類資產。該組合自2009年啟動以來一直保持不俗的成績，成立至今的平均內部回報率年率約12%，而隨着政府「未來基金」部分投放於該組合，我們加快了投資步伐，去年底「長期增長組合」的資產規模約1,818億港元，已批出但未提取作投資的總額約1,338億港元。外匯基金將繼續恪守「保本先行、長期增值」的投資策略，在保持充裕的流動性和備用資金的前提下，尋求長遠穩定的回報。

# Chief Executive’s Statement

In 2016, “black swans” frequently appeared on the global political and economic stage. While the Brexit referendum and the U.S. presidential election results made various polls appear laughable, even more surprising was the reaction of the financial markets. Take the U.S. election as an example: news of Trump’s victory caused major U.S. stock index futures to plunge sharply before markets opened, but shortly after opening, the stock indices rebounded, subsequently reaching new highs with triumphant celebrations. These series of events highlight the limitations of traditional wisdom and thinking in predicting market movements, and mark significant uncertainties in the future development of the global situation.

Over the past year, many key financial data reflected an abnormally sensitive market sentiment: after the U.S. ten-year Treasury yield hit a record low of 1.36% in July, it shot up to 2.6% in mid-December following the U.S. presidential election. The USD index, which reflects the trend of the U.S. dollar against a basket of currencies, rose to a 14-year high at the end of the year; meanwhile, crude oil futures prices rebounded from a low of US$26 per barrel at the beginning of the year to US$54 at year-end. In our local stock market, the Hang Seng Index saw a marginal increase of 86 points for the whole year, but within the period, the peak-to-trough difference exceeded 6,000 points. External shocks and tumultuous conditions further underscore the importance and preciousness of the stability of the financial system, particularly the monetary and banking sectors.

In January 2016, rumours ran rampant about international hedge funds deploying strategies to target the renminbi and Hong Kong dollar, causing widespread panic. The Hong Kong Monetary Authority promptly issued clear and firm messages to the market: we are confident and capable of defending the Linked Exchange Rate System and the stability of Hong Kong’s financial system, thus stabilizing market confidence in a timely manner. Throughout 2016, the Hong Kong dollar remained close to the strong-side convertibility undertaking. Due to ample liquidity in the banking system, even with the U.S. Federal Reserve raising interest rates in December last year and in March this year, there was no obvious immediate impact on the Hong Kong dollar interest rates or exchange rate.

The banking sector continued to develop steadily. Overall loans grew modestly by 6.5% last year, with asset quality maintained at a good level; non-performing loan ratio remained at a healthy 0.85%, well below the long-term average of about 2% since 2000. Capital adequacy and liquidity ratios also remained at high levels above statutory requirements. In the property mortgage sector, after seven rounds of countercyclical measures, the average loan-to-value ratio for new residential properties declined from 64% in September 2009 to 51% at the end of 2016, and the average debt-service ratio also decreased from 41% in August 2010 to 34% at year-end, providing buffers against potential shocks when the property cycle turns. The Hong Kong Monetary Authority will continue to closely monitor the property market development and adopt appropriate measures according to the cycle’s changes to maintain banking system stability.

Legislative progress last year further strengthened the stability of the banking system. The two laws aimed at optimising the deposit protection scheme and establishing resolution mechanisms to prevent “too big to fail” risks for financial institutions were approved in a timely manner before the previous Legislative Council term ended. The former accelerates the disbursement of deposit protection funds and simplifies procedures, which helps bolster depositors’ confidence in the banking system. The latter provides a resolution framework for financial institutions, including banks, to guard against systemic risks caused by their potential insolvency and to reduce reliance on public funds for bailouts. The HKMA established the Resolution Office on April 1 this year to ensure the proper implementation of the legal requirements and ongoing follow-up work.

Banks are known as the “mother of all industries,” as they are vital to the real economy and the daily lives of ordinary citizens—serving as the main channels for savings, payments, and credit needs. During the year, some representative of small and medium enterprises (SMEs) expressed concerns over financing difficulties. The HKMA immediately engaged in communication with the banking sector, encouraging banks to continue to support SME operations and development while maintaining prudent risk management. We also promoted the Government’s “SME Financing Guarantee Scheme” through the HKMC and worked closely with banks to allay concerns, clarify procedures for claims on bad debts, and streamline processes, thereby increasing banks’ willingness to participate. These efforts have achieved certain results: a survey conducted by the HKMA showed that overall SME credit limits remained stable last year, with over 90% of enterprises maintaining or even increasing their credit limits. Meanwhile, the number of applications under the scheme also increased significantly.

In recent years, the HKMA has vigorously promoted financial inclusion, recognizing that basic banking services are essential for businesses and daily life. After learning that some overseas companies and startups faced difficulties opening accounts in Hong Kong, we promptly followed up by contacting multiple chambers of commerce and business associations, and working closely with the banking sector to resolve issues. In September last year, I issued a notice to all banks in Hong Kong, explaining how to interpret and apply the “risk-based” regulatory principles in anti-money laundering and counter-terrorist financing activities—especially in account opening and customer due diligence procedures—emphasizing that banks should not adopt a “one size fits all” approach for every customer. After negotiations with the banking sector and trade associations, the situation has improved, although there remains room for further enhancement, which will be one of our focuses this year.

Financial inclusion also pertains to expanding the coverage of banking services through branch networks. The HKMA has been encouraging banks to balance profit motives with citizens’ basic banking needs. With the rapid development of financial technology, service channels are becoming more diverse. In addition to increasingly popular online banking, many banks introduced mobile branches and video teller machines last year to provide more personalized and comprehensive banking services. Under our promotion, several banks also plan to set up physical branches in remote areas to better serve local residents.

As an international financial centre, Hong Kong’s development is like sailing against the current—the pursuit of new opportunities has been ongoing for many years. In 2016, this effort bore fruitful results, especially in financial technology (Fintech) and infrastructure financing.  

In the Fintech domain, Hong Kong’s retail payment services entered a new era in 2016. The HKMA issued 13 stored value facilities licenses last year, creating a conducive environment for retail payment service providers through licensing and the ongoing regulatory regime, complemented by a series of public education campaigns. This ensures consumers enjoy the convenience brought by new technology while their rights are protected.

Additionally, in March last year, the HKMA established the Fintech Facilitation Office as a platform to promote related developments in banking. Several new initiatives were launched within months, including the Cybersecurity Fortification Initiative, which established a tripartite platform for risk assessment, information sharing, and talent training to strengthen the cybersecurity of the banking system. We also collaborated with the Hong Kong Applied Science and Technology Research Institute (ASTRI) to carry out research on distributed ledger technology, exploring its feasibility for application in Hong Kong’s banking sector, and established the Fintech Innovation Hub to support technological development in the industry. The HKMA’s banking supervision department also set up a Fintech Supervisory Sandbox, allowing banks to test new technologies on a smaller and controlled scale, thereby accelerating the development of new products and services. From September last year to March this year, six banks conducted tests on 14 new technology projects within the sandbox, with some projects already launched to the market, bringing new fintech products to citizens.

Globally, there is an enormous demand for infrastructure financing—especially since the “Belt and Road” Initiative has garnered international attention. Hong Kong, as Asia’s international financial hub, has distinct advantages in this area. In July last year, the HKMA established the Infrastructure Financing Facilitation Office (IFFO), creating a unique platform to connect more than 60 world-class multilateral agencies, institutional investors, banks, insurance companies, other financial institutions, infrastructure project developers and operators, and professional service providers to exchange information, share experiences, and seek cooperation on infrastructure investment and financing. Since its inception, IFFO has held over ten major conferences, seminars, and workshops. The HKMA has also signed memoranda of understanding with the International Finance Corporation, Global Infrastructure Hub, China Development Bank, and the Export-Import Bank of China to jointly promote infrastructure investment and financing activities. Although still in its early stages, these efforts lay a solid foundation for Hong Kong’s future role as an infrastructure financing centre.

Removing barriers is a key to enhancing competitiveness. During the year, the HKMA actively participated in and supported the SAR Government’s amendments to the tax law, aiming to create a favourable tax environment for enterprises operating in Hong Kong’s corporate treasury business. We also proactively engaged with multinational companies to attract them to develop or expand their treasury activities here, further strengthening the function of Hong Kong’s financial market.

Last year, the offshore renminbi market experienced a period of adjustment. Due to market volatility and expectations concerning the renminbi’s exchange rate, the size of the offshore renminbi liquidity pool contracted globally. Nevertheless, Hong Kong maintained its position as the world’s largest renminbi offshore hub, with the renminbi traded through Hong Kong maintaining an average daily volume of approximately RMB 8.6 trillion, remaining at a high level. To further optimize liquidity arrangements in Hong Kong’s offshore renminbi market, we increased the number of primary liquidity providers from seven to nine last October, raising the total support capacity for bilateral liquidity to RMB 18 billion, ensuring market orderly operation even when offshore renminbi liquidity tightens. The “Shenzhen-Hong Kong Stock Connect” program was launched in December last year, injecting fresh momentum into Hong Kong’s renminbi business. The HKMA is also working with mainland authorities on the “Bond Connect” scheme to facilitate bond market participation and connect infrastructure.

Despite the many uncertainties in the global investment environment last year, our past defensive preparations paid off—resulting in an investment income of HK$68.1 billion for the Exchange Fund. Since 1994, the compound annual return of the Fund has been 4.8%, surpassing the 2.1% local inflation rate during the same period.

The Exchange Fund will continue to promote diversified investments, including expanding asset classes, increasing holdings of credit assets, inflation-linked investment products, and investments in emerging markets. The flagship “Long-Term Growth Portfolio,” which involves investments in alternative assets such as private equity and real estate, has performed remarkably since its inception in 2009, with an average annual internal rate of return of about 12%. As the government has allocated part of the “Future Fund” into this portfolio, we have accelerated our investment pace. By the end of last year, the asset size of the “Long-Term Growth Portfolio” reached approximately HK$181.8 billion, with an outstanding committed but unexercised investment amount of about HK$133.8 billion. The Exchange Fund will uphold the principle of “capital preservation first, long-term value growth next,” maintaining ample liquidity and reserves while seeking long-term stable returns.

# 2016年摘要

# 經濟及金融環境

隨着環球經濟及貿易活動疲弱，香港經濟增長回軟。年內本港股市及住宅物業市場波動，置業負擔能力依然偏緊。

儘管環球市場風險及衝擊增加，香港銀行體系仍維持穩健。銀行資本及流動性狀況維持良好；資產質素輕微轉差，但仍處於健康水平。

# 貨幣穩定

儘管面對波動的外圍環境，港元匯率仍然保持穩定，反映聯繫匯率制度承受外來衝擊的能力。

貨幣市場繼續運作暢順，銀行同業流動資金充裕。於12月，繼美國聯邦儲備局決定上調聯邦基金利率目標範圍，香港基本利率上調25基點至1.00厘。

# 銀行體系穩定

金管局加強監管銀行的風險管治架構，以及信用、流動性與科技風險管理。金管局亦採取具體行動，促進普及金融和應對企業在香港開立及維持銀行帳戶遇到的困難。

監管政策方面，就本港實施國際監管及會計標準的準備工作取得重大進展，當中包括《金融機構（處置機制）條例》下的處置框架。

# 香港的國際金融中心地位

香港維持其作為全球離岸人民幣業務樞紐和資產管理中心的地位。稅制獲進一步完善，營造更有利環境，吸引跨國公司在香港設立企業財資中心。

為發展香港成為基建融資中心與金融科技樞紐，金管局成立基建融資促進辦公室及金融科技促進辦公室。金管局順利開始實施儲值支付工具及零售支付系統的監管制度，並批出13個儲值支付工具牌照。

# 儲備管理

儘管投資環境困難，充斥黑天鵝事件，但有賴過去幾年所採取的一連串防禦措施，增強外匯基金的抗震能力，外匯基金錄得2%的整體投資回報。

金管局加快多元化投資的步伐，特別是長期增長組合的投資。

# 機構職能

金管局透過傳媒、公眾教育活動及其他各種渠道與社會和市場保持有效溝通，增進公眾對金管局政策及運作的了解。

金管局繼續加強機構管治，包括推動員工提升專業能力、嚴格控制財政及加強資訊科技保安，以應付推行新措施及日益繁重的工作所帶來的挑戰。

# 2016 Summary

# Economic and Financial Environment

As global economic and trade activities weakened, Hong Kong’s economic growth slowed down. During the year, the local stock market and residential property market experienced volatility, and housing affordability remained tight.

Despite increased risks and shocks in the global markets, the Hong Kong banking sector remained resilient. Banks' capital and liquidity positions remained strong; asset quality slightly deteriorated but still stayed at healthy levels.

# Currency Stability

Despite the volatile external environment, the Hong Kong dollar exchange rate remained stable, reflecting the resilience of the linked exchange rate system against external shocks.

The money market continued to operate smoothly, and interbank liquidity was ample. In December, following the U.S. Federal Reserve’s decision to raise the federal funds rate target range, Hong Kong’s base rate was increased by 25 basis points to 1.00%.

# Banking System Stability

The HKMA strengthened its risk governance framework for banks, including credit, liquidity, and technology risk management. The HKMA also took concrete actions to promote financial accessibility and to address difficulties faced by enterprises in opening and maintaining bank accounts in Hong Kong.

In terms of regulatory policies, significant progress was achieved in preparations for implementing international regulatory and accounting standards applicable in Hong Kong, including the resolution framework under the Banking (Resolution) Ordinance.

# Hong Kong’s International Financial Centre Status

Hong Kong maintained its position as a global offshore Renminbi business hub and asset management centre. The tax regime was further improved to create a more conducive environment, attracting multinational companies to establish corporate treasury centres in Hong Kong.

To develop Hong Kong as an infrastructure financing centre and a financial technology hub, the HKMA established the Infrastructure Financing Facilitation Office and the Fintech Facilitation Office. The HKMA also successfully launched the regulatory regime for stored value facilities and retail payment systems, issuing 13 stored value facility licences.

# Reserves Management

Despite a challenging investment environment filled with black swan events, past measures enhanced the resilience of the Exchange Fund, which recorded an overall investment return of 2%.

The HKMA accelerated diversification of investments, especially in the long-term growth portfolio.

# Institutional Functions

The HKMA actively communicated with society and markets through media, public education activities, and other channels to improve public understanding of its policies and operations.

The HKMA continued to strengthen corporate governance, including promoting staff professional development, exercising strict financial controls, and enhancing information technology security to meet the challenges of implementing new measures and increasing workload.

# 經濟及金融環境

隨着環球經濟及貿易活動疲弱，香港經濟增長在2016年回軟。面對外圍環境不明朗因素加劇，預期2017年經濟增長仍然溫和。

# 經濟回顧

# 概覽

香港經濟增長在2016年放緩，實質本地生產總值增長由2015年的2.4%降至1.9%（表1）。淨出口是主要拖累，當中訪港旅遊業疲弱令服務輸出受壓（圖1）。本地需求動力亦放緩，但繼續為整體經濟增長提供主要支持。勞工市場大致保持穩定，失業率維持於3.3至3.4%的低位。由於本地成本及外部價格壓力減退，消費物價通脹進一步放緩。面對波動的外圍環境及多變的市場氣氛，資產市場增添起伏。鑑於住宅物業市場再度暢旺，政府於11月實施新印花稅措施。

儘管外圍環境波動及美元利率上升，本港外匯及貨幣市場繼續運作暢順。港元現貨匯率於1月份略為轉弱後一直在7.75附近水平徘徊。年內兌換保證並無被觸發，總結餘與未償還外匯基金票據及債券合計幾乎維持不變，約為1.2萬億港元。繼美國於12月中加息後，金管局基本利率由0.75厘上調至1厘。香港銀行同業拆息及較長期債券收益率維持在相對較低水平，但在接近年底時稍升，部分反映美元相應拆息及收益率的走勢。整體銀行貸款增長在2016年加快至6.5%。雖然整體貸款質素略為轉差，但特定分類貸款比率仍然維持在極低水平。

圖 1 組成部分對實質本地生產總值增長的貢獻
資料來源：政府統計處。

表 1 按開支項目計的實質本地生產總值增長（比對上期）

資料來源：政府統計處。

# 本地需求

本地需求的增長力度在2016年略為減弱。儘管穩定的就業及收入狀況繼續為私人消費帶來支持，但其增速仍降至1.6%，部分反映經濟不明朗因素加劇。政府消費增長亦略為減慢至3.3%。本地固定資本形成總額繼續按季大幅上落（圖2），累計全年收縮0.5%。私營部門機器及設備購置成為主要拖累，在營商前景欠佳下連續第3年收縮，而樓宇及建造活動則因住屋動工項目增加而轉殷。

圖 2 本地需求
資料來源：政府統計處。

# 外部需求

香港出口在接近2016年底時有回穩跡象，但綜合全年表現仍然乏力（圖3）。貨品出口較2015年的低基數上升1.7%。香港對先進經濟體的出口仍然呆滯；但在區內貿易流動轉趨穩定下，香港對中國內地、印度、韓國、新加坡及台灣的出口則較2015年好轉。

部分反映零售銷售在近年急速增長後轉趨正常化，香港服務輸出在2016年顯著收縮3.1%。貨品進口在2015年收縮後於2016年收復部分失地，服務輸入則部分受惠於本地居民外遊意欲而持續增長。2016年整體貿易順差收窄，拖累本地經濟增長。

圖 3 貨品出口及服務輸出
資料來源：政府統計處。

# 通脹

通脹壓力在2016年仍然受控。剔除政府一次性紓緩措施的影響後，基本通脹率由2015年的2.5%下降至2016年的2.3%（圖4）。在早前新訂私人住宅租金下調所帶來的傳遞效應下，綜合消費物價指數中的租金組成項目通脹回落。受惠於全球商品價格偏軟及港元強勢，進口價格通脹受到遏抑。另一方面，在勞工成本穩定增長及租金成本壓力（尤其零售範疇）有所紓緩下，本地成本壓力保持溫和。

圖 4 基本消費物價通脹
資料來源：政府統計處。

# 勞工市場

勞工市場在2016年大致保持穩定，勞工供求升幅相若。按行業分析，旅遊相關行業的勞工市場狀況轉差，其他行業則大致平穩。整體而言，經季節因素調整失業率由2015年的3.3%稍升至3.4%（圖5）。在勞工市場穩定下，名義工資在首3季上升3.8%，而2015年的升幅為4.6%。首3季實質工資亦上升0.9%，而2015年的升幅為1.5%。

圖 5 勞工市場狀況
資料來源：政府統計處。

# 股市

香港股市在2016年大幅上落。受到人民幣貶值壓力及內地股市波動所影響，恒生指數於2月份跌至3年來的低位（圖6）。本港股市在3月份跟隨美國及其他主要股市顯著造好而回升。儘管英國脫歐公投觸發市場波動，但在外界預期美國聯邦儲備局會放緩加息步伐及其他主要央行推行貨幣寬鬆政策下，市場氣氛迅速改善。恒生指數於9月份升至24,100點的一年高位。然而，受到美國總統選舉結果及預計美國會加快加息步伐所影響，本港股市在第4季再度受壓。整體而言，恒生指數於2016年微升0.4%，在2015年則下跌7.2%。平均每日成交額由上年的1,056億港元降至669億港元，而本港股市集資總額亦由上年的11,156億港元減少至4,901億港元。

圖 6 資產價格
資料來源：差餉物業估價署及香港交易及結算所有限公司。

# 物業市場

住宅物業市場在2016年略為波動。物業成交量於第1季錄得歷史新低後，在其後數月有所回升，但在11月推出新印花稅措施後再度下挫。整體而言，成交量在2016年稍跌至54,701宗。另一方面，樓價自第2季起上升並超越2015年9月的高位，2016年的累計升幅為7.8%（圖6）。置業負擔能力依然偏緊，樓價與收入比率為15.9，超越1997年的歷史高位；而收入槓桿比率為72.0%，遠高於長期平均水平。2 由於銀行推出具競爭力的按揭計劃，按揭利率稍為回落，於接近年底時則跟隨香港銀行同業拆息上升而略為回升。工商物業市場方面，全年交投大致保持穩定。由於非住宅物業價格較2015年高位回落，相應租金收益率較上年微升，但仍處於低位。

# 經濟前景

# 經濟環境

預期2017年實質本地生產總值增長將保持溫和。政府預測經濟增長幅度介乎2至3%之間，私營機構分析員預測增幅平均為2.0%。外圍方面，隨着環球宏觀經濟及金融環境變得不明朗，全球經濟及貿易增長或會保持溫和；再加上港元實質有效匯率因美元強勢而上升，將會抑制香港的出口表現。本地方面，雖然穩定的就業及收入狀況會支持消費，但受利率上升所拖累，預期私人消費會溫和增長。受惠於住屋供應增加及多個基建項目展開，樓宇及建造活動應會穩步增長，但營商氣氛疲弱及利率趨升將影響商界資本投資。

# 通脹及勞工市場

預計2017年通脹壓力仍然溫和。一方面環球商品價格上漲及中國內地通脹趨升或會令進口價格上升，另一方面港元轉強卻可能會令上述壓力受到遏抑。在溫和的經濟動力下，本地成本壓力仍可受控，但由於新訂住宅租金於2017年初上升，綜合消費物價指數中的租金組成項目通脹可能會稍升。市場共識預測2017年整體通脹率為1.9%，政府預期基本通脹率為2.0%。雖然不明朗因素加劇或會影響招聘意欲，私營機構分析員預計2017年失業率會維持於3.4%。

# 不明朗因素及風險

2017年經濟前景會受制於眾多不明朗因素，當中來自外圍環境的影響尤甚。美國新一屆政府政策的不確定性，將令環球經濟前景變得不明朗，當中可能出現的保護主義政策亦會對全球貿易帶來阻力。英國脫歐進程及歐洲幾個主要國家舉行大選，亦可能導致資產市場波動，並影響港元資金流向。此外，美國利率正常化將會令本地貨幣狀況收緊，並對實質經濟及資產價格構成下調壓力；當中樓市繼續偏緊，市場前景仍然很不明朗。短期而言，按揭息率仍然偏低、就業及收入狀況穩定，以及地產發展商加推優惠（例如折扣及現金回贈）令累積的購買力獲得釋放，均可為住宅需求帶來支持。另一方面，新印花稅措施、美國可能加快加息步伐及房屋供應穩步增長，則可能繼續為樓市帶來阻力。

# 銀行體系表現

儘管本港經濟面對阻力，加上國際政治事件出乎意料的結果令市場波動加劇，香港銀行體系在2016年仍然穩健。認可機構的資本及流動性狀況維持良好，資產質素輕微轉差，但仍處於健康水平。

# 利率走勢

隨着美國利率上升，香港銀行同業拆息在11月及12月顯著上升。反映零售銀行港元資金成本的綜合利率則輕微上升（圖7）。

# 盈利走勢

零售銀行在2016年的盈利略為改善，其香港業務的整體除稅前經營溢利增長8.7%。增長主要是由外匯及衍生工具業務收入（+39.7%）、附屬公司派發的股息收入（+123.5%）及淨利息收入（+2.8%）所帶動，不過部份增長被費用及佣金收入減少(-11.3%)所抵銷。零售銀行除稅後溢利錄得44.4%的升幅，增長主要來自非經常項目。零售銀行除稅後平均資產回報率亦相應由2015 年的 1.04% 上升至 1.44%（圖 8）。

圖8 零售銀行的表現

2016年零售銀行淨息差為1.32%，與2015年的水平相同（圖9）。雖然零售銀行繼續將剩餘資金配置於息率較低而流動性較高的金融投資，但利息收益的減少被利息成本下降所抵銷。

# Economic and Financial Environment

As global economic and trade activities weaken, Hong Kong's economic growth slowed in 2016. Facing increasing uncertainties in the external environment, it is expected that economic growth in 2017 will remain moderate.

# Economic Review

# Overview

Hong Kong's economic growth slowed in 2016, with real local GDP growth decreasing from 2.4% in 2015 to 1.9% (Table 1). Net exports were the main drag, notably with weak arrivals tourism depressing service exports (Figure 1). Domestic demand also decelerated but continued to support overall economic growth. The labor market remained broadly stable, with the unemployment rate at a low 3.3% to 3.4%. Due to easing pressures on local costs and external prices, consumer price inflation further slowed. Amid volatile external conditions and variable market sentiment, asset markets experienced fluctuations. Thanks to a robust rebound in the residential property market, the government implemented new stamp duty measures in November.

Despite external volatility and rising U.S. interest rates, the Hong Kong dollar and currency markets continued to function smoothly. The HKD spot exchange rate weakened slightly in January and then hovered around 7.75. No exchange guarantee was triggered during the year. The total reserves balance combined with outstanding Exchange Fund paper and bonds remained stable at about HK$1.2 trillion. Following the U.S. rate hike in mid-December, the HKMA's base rate was increased from 0.75% to 1%. Hong Kong interbank lending rates and yields on longer-term bonds remained at relatively low levels but rose slightly toward year-end, partly reflecting movements in U.S. interest rates and yields. Overall bank lending growth accelerated to 6.5% in 2016. Although loan quality slightly declined, the proportion of classified loans remained at very low levels.

Source: Census and Statistics Department.

Table 1 Real GDP Growth by Expenditure Item (Compared with Previous Period)

Note: Seasonally adjusted quarter-to-quarter changes in total local fixed asset formation are not specified.
Source: Census and Statistics Department.

# Domestic Demand

Growth in domestic demand slightly weakened in 2016. Despite stable employment and income supporting private consumption, its growth slowed to 1.6%, partly reflecting increased economic uncertainties. Government expenditure growth also slowed slightly to 3.3%. Total fixed asset formation experienced large quarterly fluctuations (Figure 2), culminating in a 0.5% contraction for the year. Private sector machinery and equipment purchases were the main drag, contracting for the third consecutive year amid poor business outlook, while construction and building activities increased due to more housing start projects.

Figure 2 Domestic Demand
Source: Census and Statistics Department.

# External Demand

Hong Kong exports showed signs of stabilization near the end of 2016, but overall performance remained weak over the year (Figure 3). Goods exports rose 1.7% from a low base in 2015. Exports to advanced economies remained sluggish; however, with trade flows within the region becoming more stable, exports to Mainland China, India, Korea, Singapore, and Taiwan improved compared to 2015.

Partly reflecting the normalization of retail sales after rapid growth, Hong Kong’s service exports contracted sharply by 3.1% in 2016. Goods imports recovered some ground after contracting in 2015, while services imports continued to grow, benefiting from residents’ outward travel propensity. Overall, Hong Kong's trade surplus narrowed in 2016, weighing on local economic growth.

Figure 3 Goods Exports and Service Outputs
Source: Census and Statistics Department.

# Inflation

Inflationary pressures remained controlled in 2016. Excluding the impact of one-off government relief measures, core inflation decreased from 2.5% in 2015 to 2.3% in 2016 (Figure 4). The pass-through effect of earlier reductions in private residential rents contributed to a slowdown in rent component inflation within the Consumer Price Index. With softer global commodity prices and a firm HKD, import price inflation was subdued. Conversely, moderate growth in labor costs and easing rent pressures—especially in retail—kept domestic costs relatively mild.

Figure 4 Core Consumer Price Inflation
Source: Census and Statistics Department.

# Labour Market

The labor market remained broadly stable in 2016, with demand and supply growth roughly balanced. Industry analysis shows that employment conditions in tourism-related sectors deteriorated, while others remained steady. Overall, seasonally adjusted unemployment edged up slightly from 3.3% in 2015 to 3.4% (Figure 5). Nominal wages increased by 3.8% in the first three quarters, down from 4.6% in 2015. Real wages in the same period grew by 0.9%, slower than 1.5% in 2015.

Figure 5 Labour Market Conditions
Source: Census and Statistics Department.

# Stock Market

Hong Kong shares experienced substantial volatility in 2016. Pressure from renminbi depreciation and mainland stock market fluctuations pushed the Hang Seng Index down to a three-year low in February (Figure 6). In March, the market rebounded significantly following the recovery of U.S. and other major markets. Despite market turbulence triggered by Brexit referendum, expectations that the U.S. Federal Reserve would slow the pace of rate hikes and major central banks’ monetary easing improved investor sentiment. The Hang Seng Index reached a high of 24,100 in September. However, as a result of the U.S. presidential election and expectations of faster rate hikes, the market weakened again in the last quarter. Overall, the Hang Seng Index slightly increased by 0.4% in 2016, contrasting with a decline of 7.2% in 2015. Daily average turnover dropped from HK$105.6 billion in the previous year to HK$66.9 billion, and total capital raised in the local stock market decreased from HK$1,115.6 billion to HK$490.1 billion.

Figure 6 Asset Prices
Source: Rating and Valuation Department and Hong Kong Exchanges and Clearing Limited.

# Property Market

The residential property market experienced some fluctuations in 2016. After hitting the lowest level on record in the first quarter, transaction volume recovered over the subsequent months but declined again after the new stamp duty measures were introduced in November. Overall, transactions for the year slightly fell to 54,701. Meanwhile, property prices rose from the second quarter onward, surpassing the September 2015 high, with cumulative growth of 7.8% in 2016 (Figure 6). Housing affordability remained tight, with the price-to-income ratio at 15.9, exceeding the 1997 peak; the income leverage ratio stood at 72.0%, well above the long-term average. Thanks to competitive mortgage plans introduced by banks, mortgage interest rates slightly declined but edged up again toward year-end as Hong Kong interbank offered rates increased. The commercial property sector saw stable trading volume over the year. Prices declined from their 2015 peaks, and the corresponding rental yields rose slightly year-on-year but remained low.

# Economic Outlook

# Economic Environment

Real GDP growth is projected to stay moderate in 2017. The government forecasts growth of 2-3%, with private sector analysts expecting an average of 2.0%. External outlook remains uncertain amid global macroeconomic and financial environment ambiguities, likely resulting in continued moderate growth of the world economy and trade. The appreciation of the effective real exchange rate of the HKD against the backdrop of a strong USD will weigh on Hong Kong’s export performance. Domestically, stable employment and income conditions will support consumption, but rising interest rates are expected to lead to modest growth in private consumption. Increased housing supply and ongoing infrastructure projects should support steady growth in building and construction activities, but weak business sentiment and rising interest rates could dampen corporate capital investment.

# Inflation and Labour Market

Inflationary pressures are expected to remain modest in 2017. Global commodity prices and rising inflation in Mainland China may lift import prices, but a strengthening HKD could offset these pressures. Under moderate economic momentum, local costs will stay contained, but rents for new private residential units are expected to rise early in 2017, possibly pushing up rent components within the CPI slightly. Market consensus points to an overall inflation rate of 1.9% for 2017, with the government projecting a basic inflation rate of 2.0%. Increased uncertainty in the market may impact hiring intentions, but private sector analysts forecast unemployment to remain at 3.4%.

# Uncertainties and Risks

The 2017 economic outlook faces many uncertainties, especially external ones. U.S. policy uncertainty under the new administration could bring increased unpredictability to the global outlook, with protectionist measures possibly hampering trade. Brexit and upcoming elections in major European countries may cause asset market fluctuations and influence capital flows into the HKD. Additionally, normalization of U.S. interest rates will tighten financial conditions locally and exert downward pressures on the economy and asset prices, particularly in the housing market, where demand remains tight amid ongoing uncertainties. In the short term, low mortgage rates, stable employment and income, and incentives from developers (such as discounts and cash rebates) may support housing demand. Conversely, new stamp duty measures, potential faster U.S. rate hikes, and steady housing supply growth could continue to pose headwinds for the property market.

# Banking System Performance

Despite economic headwinds and unexpected geopolitical developments causing market volatility, Hong Kong's banking system remained resilient in 2016. The capital and liquidity positions of authorized institutions stayed healthy, asset quality slightly deteriorated but remaining sound.

# Interest Rate Trends

Following U.S. rate hikes, Hong Kong's interbank offered rates spiked notably in November and December. The composite rate reflecting retail banking costs of HKD funds increased slightly (Figure 7).

# Profitability Trends

Retail banking profits improved slightly in 2016, with pre-tax operating profit increasing by 8.7% overall. Growth was driven mainly by income from foreign exchange and derivatives (+39.7%), dividends received from subsidiaries (+123.5%), and net interest income (+2.8%), though some gains were offset by a decrease in expenses and commissions (-11.3%). After tax, retail banking profit surged by 44.4%, mainly due to non-recurring items. The average return on assets of retail banks increased from 1.04% in 2015 to 1.44% (Figure 8).

Figure 8 Performance of Retail Banks

In 2016, net interest margin of retail banks remained at 1.32%, similar to 2015 levels (Figure 9). Although retail banks continued to allocate surplus funds to low-yield, high-liquidity financial investments, the decline in interest income was offset by reduced interest expenses.

Figure 9 Net Interest Margin of Retail Banks

The proportion of non-interest income in total operating income stayed at about 44.3%. Despite an 11.3% decline in expenses and commissions, dividends and income from foreign exchange and derivatives increased by 123.5% and 39.7%, respectively.

# 貨幣穩定

儘管外圍環境波動及美元息率上升，港元匯率在2016年仍然保持穩定。香港貨幣市場亦繼續運作暢順，銀行同業流動資金充裕。聯繫匯率制度繼續展現高度承受衝擊的能力，是香港貨幣及金融穩定的基石。

# 目標

香港貨幣政策的主要目標是維持貨幣穩定，即確保港元匯價穩定，使港元在外匯市場兌美元的匯率保持在7.75至7.85港元兌1美元的區間內。該貨幣體制主要採用貨幣發行局制度，規定由外匯基金所持的美元儲備向貨幣基礎提供最少百分之百的支持；貨幣基礎若有變動，美元儲備亦必須作出相應增減，與貨幣基礎的變動百分之百配合。

貨幣基礎（表1）包括：
- 負債證明書（為3間發鈔銀行發行的銀行紙幣提供十足支持）
- 政府發行的流通紙幣及硬幣
- 銀行在金管局所持結算戶口的結餘總額（即總結餘）
- 金管局代表政府發行的外匯基金票據及債券。

表1 貨幣基礎

金管局透過自動利率調節機制及履行兌換保證的堅決承諾來維持港元匯率的穩定。若市場對港元的需求大過供應，令市場匯率轉強至7.75港元兌1美元的強方兌換保證匯率，金管局會向銀行沽出港元、買入美元，使總結餘增加及港元利率下跌，從而令港元匯率從強方兌換保證匯率水平回復至7.75到7.85的兌換範圍內。相反，若港元供過於求，令市場匯率轉弱至7.85港元兌1美元的弱方兌換保證匯率，金管局會向銀行買入港元，使總結餘減少及推高港元利率，港元匯率隨之由弱方兌換保證匯率水平回復至兌換範圍內。

# 2016年回顧

# 匯率穩定

港元匯率在2016年首兩個月略有波動後，於年內餘下時間一直窄幅徘徊。港元在2016年初兌美元顯著轉弱，由1月4日的7.7510降至1月20日的7.8196（圖1）。港元匯率轉弱符合聯繫匯率制度的正常運作，反映美國在2015年12月加息後港元與美元的負息差擴濶。此外，其他市場相關因素，包括香港股市出現拋售、內地及香港經濟前景不及以前樂觀、人民幣匯率波動增加，以及亞洲貨幣普遍疲弱，均導致港元需求減弱。受到市場氣氛改善支持，港元匯率在2月略為轉強，並自3月起一直在7.753至7.776之間窄幅徘徊，即使英國脫歐公投及美國總統選舉引發市場波動亦未受影響。由於市場預期美國會在夏季加息，港元匯率於5月出現短暫的轉弱壓力。整體而言，港元外匯市場在2016年一直正常運作。

圖 1 2016年市場匯率

由於兌換保證沒有被觸發，因此總結餘及未償還外匯基金票據及債券總額在2016年沒有明顯變動，大致維持在12,222億港元左右（圖2）。年內金管局增發總值1,320億港元的外匯基金票據，以滿足銀行在流動性管理方面的龐大需求，令總結餘相應減少至2016年底的2,596億港元。增發外匯基金票據符合貨幣發行局制度的原則，這是由於增發外匯基金票據只屬貨幣基礎組成部分之間的轉移，即由總結餘移至未償還外匯基金票據及債券，貨幣基礎仍然由外匯儲備提供十足支持。

圖 2 2016年總結餘及未償還外匯基金票據及債券

# 貨幣市場

香港銀行同業拆息在2016年大部分時間維持在較低水平（圖3）。香港銀行同業拆息在1、2月期間因金融市場波動加劇而面對一些上升壓力，但在3月隨着金融環境回復平靜而轉趨穩定。於第2及第3季，儘管市場關注英國脫歐公投結果以及美國貨幣市場基金改革，香港銀行同業拆息仍大致保持穩定。部分受到年底資金需求影響，以及港元拆息追回美元拆息的升幅，香港銀行同業拆息在第4季錄得較大升幅。儘管如此，短期銀行同業拆息在2016年大致維持在低於基本利率的水平。

因應美國聯邦基金利率目標範圍於12月14日（美國時間）由0.25至0.50厘上調至0.50至0.75厘，基本利率於12月15日由0.75厘上調至1.00厘。基本利率的調整是按照於2009年3月26日宣布的經修訂計算公式作出。按照該公式，基本利率定於美國聯邦基金利率目標範圍下限加50基點的水平，或隔夜與1個月香港銀行同業拆息的5天移動平均數的平均值水平，兩者以較高者為準。

圖 3 2016年香港銀行同業拆息

港元遠期匯率點子在1月出現大幅溢價，大致跟隨港元與美元息差的走勢，以及部分反映投資者為其港股組合作出外匯對沖的需求（圖4）。遠期匯率溢價在2月開始收窄。隨着市況轉趨穩定，港元遠期匯率點子在3至11月期間大致保持穩定，其後在12月因港元與美元息差收窄而再度上升。整體而言，香港貨幣市場運作暢順，銀行同業流動資金充裕。貼現窗借貸在2016年並不活躍，僅涉及53億港元。

# 聯繫匯率制度

儘管經歷多次區內以至全球金融危機，聯繫匯率制度（聯匯制度）過去數十年來一直是香港貨幣及金融穩定的基石。2016年初市場波動加劇，再度引起有關港元轉弱及情況有如亞洲金融危機時期的評論。為增進各界對聯匯制度的認識，金管局向公眾闡釋聯匯制度的技術細節，並指出香港金融體系有能力抵禦衝擊。政府亦重申堅決維持聯匯制度。外匯及貨幣市場穩定，進一步鞏固公眾對政府維持聯匯制度的決心以及港元作為支付及保值貨幣的信心。國際貨幣基金組織在與香港進行年度第四條磋商時，明確表示聯匯制度是最適合香港的貨幣制度，指出香港靈活的經濟結構、充裕的財政及儲備緩衝、以及穩健有效的金融監管是聯匯制度的後盾。

鑑於穩健的銀行體系對聯匯制度的正常運作具關鍵作用，金管局繼續密切監察銀行的信用、流動性及利率風險管理以及壓力測試結果，並加強對銀行個人、企業及內地相關貸款的監管，以確保銀行體系具備應付衝擊的能力。面對美國貨幣政策正常化，香港銀行同業拆息開始上升，金管局提醒市民保持警覺，並作好準備以應付可能出現的市場波動及風險。

# Currency Stability

Despite fluctuations in external environments and rising US interest rates, the Hong Kong dollar exchange rate remained stable in 2016. The Hong Kong monetary market continued to operate smoothly, with ample liquidity in interbank banking. The Linked Exchange Rate System continued to demonstrate strong resilience under shocks and is the cornerstone of Hong Kong’s monetary and financial stability.

# Objectives

Hong Kong’s main monetary policy goal is to maintain monetary stability, specifically to keep the Hong Kong dollar exchange rate stable within the interval of 7.75 to 7.85 HKD per USD on the foreign exchange market. The monetary system primarily adopts the Currency Board Arrangements, which stipulate that the US dollar reserves held by the Exchange Fund provide at least 100% backing to the monetary base. Any change in the monetary base must be matched dollar-for-dollar with corresponding increases or decreases in US dollar reserves, ensuring full support of the monetary base by foreign exchange reserves.

The monetary base (Table 1) includes:
- Certificates of indebtedness (fully supporting banknotes issued by three note-issuing banks)
- Circulating banknotes and coins issued by the government
- Total balance in the settlement accounts held by banks with the Hong Kong Monetary Authority (i.e., the aggregate balance)
- Foreign exchange fund notes and bonds issued by the Hong Kong Monetary Authority on behalf of the government.

Table 1: Monetary Base

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority maintains exchange rate stability through an automatic interest rate adjustment mechanism and a firm commitment to currency convertibility guarantees. If market demand for HKD exceeds supply, causing the exchange rate to strengthen to the strong-side convertibility rate of 7.75 HKD per USD, the HKMA will sell HKD and buy USD from banks, increasing the aggregate balance and lowering HKD interest rates. This action helps the exchange rate revert from the strong-side convertibility rate back within the 7.75–7.85 exchange rate range. Conversely, if HKD supply exceeds demand, causing the exchange rate to weaken towards the weak-side convertibility rate of 7.85 HKD per USD, the HKMA will buy HKD from banks, reducing the aggregate balance and raising HKD interest rates, thus restoring the exchange rate within the target range.

# 2016 Review

# Exchange Rate Stability

After slight fluctuations in the first two months of 2016, the HKD exchange rate largely remained within a narrow range throughout the rest of the year. In early 2016, the HKD depreciated significantly, dropping from 7.7510 on January 4 to 7.8196 on January 20 (Chart 1). The weakening of the HKD aligned with the normal operation of the Linked Exchange Rate System, reflecting a widening of the negative interest differential between HKD and USD following US rate hikes in December 2015. Additionally, other market factors, including stock sell-offs in Hong Kong, less optimistic outlooks for the Mainland and Hong Kong economies, increased RMB exchange rate volatility, and widespread weakness of Asian currencies, contributed to reduced demand for HKD. Supported by improved market sentiment, the HKD appreciated slightly in February and traded within 7.753 to 7.776 from March onwards, remaining unaffected by Brexit or US presidential election market volatility. Expectations of US interest rate hikes during summer prompted brief depreciation pressures in May. Overall, the HKD foreign exchange market operated normally throughout 2016.

*Chart 1: Market Exchange Rate in 2016*

Since the convertibility guarantee was not triggered, the total balance and the total amount of outstanding foreign exchange fund notes and bonds remained relatively unchanged in 2016, roughly maintaining around HK$1,222.2 billion (Chart 2). During the year, the HKMA issued an additional HK$132 billion of foreign exchange fund notes to meet banks’ substantial liquidity management needs, resulting in a decrease in the total balance to HK$259.6 billion by year-end. The issuance of foreign exchange fund notes aligns with the principles of the Currency Board Arrangements, representing transfers within the components of the monetary base—that is, from the total balance to the outstanding foreign exchange fund notes and bonds—while the overall backing remains fully supported by foreign exchange reserves.

*Chart 2: Total Balance and Outstanding Foreign Exchange Fund Notes and Bonds in 2016*

# Money Market

Interbank offered rates (HIBORs) in Hong Kong mostly stayed at low levels throughout 2016 (Chart 3). During January and February, Hong Kong interbank rates faced upward pressures amid financial market volatility but stabilized from March as market conditions calmed. In the second and third quarters, despite concerns over Brexit and the US money market fund reforms, the rates remained broadly stable. In the fourth quarter, due to year-end liquidity demands and the narrowing HKD–USD interest rate differential, HKHIBOR experienced a significant rise. Nevertheless, short-term interbank rates stayed generally below the basic interest rate level throughout 2016.

Following the December 14 (US time) increase in the US Federal Funds target rate from 0.25–0.50% to 0.50–0.75%, the HKMA adjusted the base rate from 0.75% to 1.00% on December 15. This adjustment follows the revised calculation formula announced on March 26, 2009, where the base rate is set at the higher of either the US Federal Funds rate target lower bound plus 50 basis points or the 5-day moving average of overnight and 1-month HKD interbank rates.

*Chart 3: Hong Kong Interbank Offered Rates in 2016*

The HKD forward points surged in January, primarily tracking the interest rate differentials between HKD and USD, and partially reflecting investor hedging needs for their Hong Kong stock portfolios (Chart 4). Forward points Premium narrowed from February. As market conditions stabilized from March to November, the forward points mostly remained stable, then rose again in December due to the narrowing interest rate differential. Overall, the Hong Kong monetary market operated smoothly with ample bank liquidity. Discount window lending was not active in 2016, involving only HK$5.3 billion.

# The Linked Exchange Rate System

Despite multiple regional and global financial crises, the Linked Exchange Rate System has been a cornerstone of Hong Kong’s monetary and financial stability for decades. Early in 2016, market volatility increased again, leading to comments about a weakening HKD and the situation resembling the Asian Financial Crisis. In response, the HKMA clarified the technical workings of the system and reiterated Hong Kong’s capacity to withstand shocks. The government reaffirmed its firm commitment to maintaining the Linked Exchange Rate System. Stable foreign exchange and money markets further solidified public confidence in the government’s resolve to uphold the system and in the HKD’s role as a medium of exchange and store of value. During the annual fourth review of the IMF, the IMF explicitly stated that the system was the most suitable monetary arrangement for Hong Kong, citing Hong Kong’s flexible economic structure, ample fiscal and reserve buffers, and robust, effective financial regulation as its backing.

*Chart 4: Forward Points of USD/HKD in 2016*

Given the critical role of a sound banking system for the normal operation of the Linked Exchange Rate System, the HKMA continues to closely monitor banks’ credit, liquidity, and interest rate risk management, as well as stress test results. It also enhances supervision of individual, corporate, and Mainland-related loans to ensure the banking sector's resilience. As US monetary policy normalizes, with HKHIBOR rising, the HKMA reminds the public to stay vigilant and be prepared for possible market volatility and risks.

To enhance transparency of the Currency Board Account, since October 1998, part of the foreign exchange reserves has been designated to support the monetary base. The support ratio (assets supporting the monetary base against the monetary base) fluctuated narrowly in 2016 between 106.3% and 107.5%, without breaching upper or lower limits. The ratio stood at 106.7% as of December 31, 2016 (Chart 5). Although certain foreign exchange reserves are designated as supporting assets under the system, the entire foreign exchange reserve can be used to support the HKD exchange rate. The large fiscal buffer of the reserves provides strong backing for Hong Kong’s monetary and financial stability in face of unexpected shocks.

*Chart 5: Daily Changes in Support Ratio in 2016*

# Research Work

The Currency Issuance Committee, under the Foreign Exchange Fund Advisory Committee, is responsible for monitoring and discussing issues related to Hong Kong’s monetary and financial stability. In 2016, topics included the synchronization of Hong Kong and Mainland China and US economic growth, external demand for the HKD, and the Hong Kong financial conditions index. Minutes of the committee meetings and the HKMA’s reports on the operation of the Currency Board Arrangements are available on the HKMA website.

The Hong Kong Institute for Monetary Research continued supporting research on monetary policy, banking, and finance. In 2016, it hosted 18 visiting scholars and published 20 working papers.

The institute organized six international seminars and conferences in 2016, including:
- The 7th Annual International Conference on the Chinese Economy in January, themed “The Deepening Impact of China on the Global Economy,” featuring eight papers on topics such as China’s growth rebalancing and potential, economic spillovers from China, RMB’s impact on global and regional economies, and inter-market yield spreads and information flows.
- The joint “Exchange Rate and Macroeconomics Conference” with HKUST and Keio University in March, addressing issues such as global economic imbalances, exchange rate dynamics, capital controls, and monetary policy.
- The “Real Estate and Financial Stability Conference” with City University in August, focusing on age, demographics, housing demand, the impact of large investors on asset quality, dynamics of housing prices in Hong Kong, affordability, the effects of mortgage regulations on household decision-making, and China's Mainland property market.
- The joint “Asia-Pacific Economies Resilience in a Volatile Global Environment” seminar with HKMA and BIS in October, attracting senior central bank officials, leading academics, and experts from international and private institutions for interactive roundtable discussions on urgent issues in the Asia-Pacific region, such as financial imbalances, capital flows, spillovers from China’s slowdown, and potential growth prospects.
- The 14th Annual Summer Workshop in August and the 14th Mainland China Economic Seminar in September, examining asset quality and financial stability in Mainland banks. These events drew academics, financial sector participants, and central bank representatives worldwide. The institute also held 21 public outreach seminars exploring broad economic, monetary, and financial issues during the year.

# Banknotes and Coins

By the end of 2016, the total value of circulation banknotes (issued by note-issuing banks) was HK$407.8 billion, representing a 13.2% increase from the previous year (Charts 6-8). The total value of government-issued circulating banknotes and coins was HK$11.8 billion, a 5.3% rise from 2015 (Charts 9-10). Among the government-issued banknotes and coins, the HK$10 circulating banknotes totaled HK$4.4 billion, of which 86% were polymer notes.

# 銀行體系穩定

儘管環球市場風險及震盪增加，香港銀行體系在2016年仍維持穩健。金管局在年內加強監管認可機構的風險管治架構，以及信用與流動性風險管理系統的成效。鑑於網絡攻擊日趨頻繁，金管局亦加強監管認可機構的科技風險管理。為貫徹金管局致力打擊金融罪行的目標，認可機構打擊洗錢及恐怖分子資金籌集監控措施的成效，繼續是金管局的監管重點。在監管認可機構的操守方面，金管局採取實質行動，推動以客為本的企業文化及促進普及金融，和應對海外中小企及初創企業在香港開立及維持銀行帳戶方面遇到的困難。金管局亦加強監管認可機構銷售投資及保險產品的手法，以進一步提升對客戶的保障。

在監管政策方面，金管局就香港實施國際監管及會計標準的準備工作取得重大進展；當中包括穩定資金淨額比率、大額風險承擔限額、國際財務報告準則第9號及《金融機構（處置機制）條例》下的處置框架。

# 2016年回顧

# 監管工作概覽

金管局在2016年共進行188次非現場審查，涵蓋範圍廣泛，包括認可機構的CAMEL評級、企業管治、業務運作及風險管理。金管局加強與認可機構董事局的聯繫，以強化銀行業的風險管治及企業文化。除與董事局或董事局委員會舉行會議外，亦另行與獨立非執行董事（獨立非執董）會面，就企業文化及風險管治事宜交換意見。金管局亦與認可機構及其外聘審計師舉行三方聯席會議。此外，金管局就認可機構的薪酬制度是否有助促進有效的風險管理進行評估。

在資本充足水平方面，金管局審視認可機構的資本計劃，包括其未來數年的資本目標，以便就2019年全面實施《巴塞爾協定三》緩衝資本作好準備。認可機構的償付能力壓力測試亦因應當前宏觀經濟環境作出改進。金管局又審慎評估各主要零售銀行的恢復計劃，並就需要改善的環節提出意見。

除了非現場審查工作外，金管局繼續以專題評估配合定期現場審查，而專題評估主要適用於被評定為較高風險的範疇。這種監管方法讓金管局更有效地調配監管資源，以應對認可機構所面對的各項新增及主要風險。金管局在2016年共進行377次現場審查及專題評估。這些審查與評估的重點仍是信用風險管理與監控，尤其涉及內地相關業務的信用風險；另一個重點是打擊洗錢及恐怖分子資金籌集監控措施。金管局又增加對流動性風險、業務操作風險及科技風險管理的現場審查及專題評估次數。年內專項審查小組亦對認可機構的證券、投資產品、保險及強制性公積金（強積金）相關業務進行現場審查。

表1載有金管局於2016年的監管工作概要。

# 信用風險的監管

# 信貸增長及資產質素

銀行貸款在2016年增長溫和。未償還貸款總額全年增加6.5%；2015年的增幅則為3.5%（表2）。由於客戶存款的增幅超過銀行貸款的增幅，整體貸存比率由2015年底的70.1%降至2016年底的68.4%。

表 2 貸款及墊款的增長

內地相關貸款總額在2016年底增加7%至35,640億港元（表3），其中包括在香港註冊的銀行設於內地的附屬公司入帳的5,450億港元貸款。

銀行業的資產質素在2016年維持穩健。儘管零售銀行的特定分類貸款比率由2015年底的0.69%微升至2016年底的0.72%，但仍遠低於2000年以來的長期平均水平2.4%。同期，整體銀行業的特定分類貸款比率由0.73%上升至0.85%。年內銀行業的內地相關貸款的資產質素呈相若走勢；同期，零售銀行這些貸款的特定分類貸款比率由0.78%微升至0.82%，整體銀行業的相關比率亦由一年前的0.77%微升至0.80%。

金管局投入大量監管資源，以確保認可機構繼續採用審慎的信貸審批標準，並維持有效的貸款分類及撥備制度。金管局在監管過程中亦特別關注認可機構對中國內地民營企業的風險承擔持續增加，以及為增加收益而投資於債務證券所引起的信用風險。此外，金管局就認可機構分銷高風險投資產品的信用風險管理進行專題評估。

# 物業按揭貸款

金管局繼續密切留意認可機構的物業貸款業務。住宅物業價格於2015年9月開始出現調整，但其後於2016年3月再度上升，全年上升8%。新造住宅物業按揭貸款的平均按揭成數，由2009年9月金管局尚未推出首輪物業貸款逆周期措施時的64%，降至2016年12月的51%。新造住宅物業按揭貸款的平均供款與入息比率亦由2010年8月首度推出供款與入息比率上限時的41%，降至2016年12月的34%（圖1）。

圖 1 新造住宅物業按揭貸款的平均按揭成數及供款與入息比率
金管局推出首輪物業貸款逆周期措施前推出供款與入息比率上限

根據金管局於2015年2月推出的第七輪逆周期措施，使用內部評級基準計算法計算信用風險資本要求的認可機構須將15%信用風險加權下限的應用，由新造按揭貸款延伸至整個住宅按揭貸款組合。這項規定於2016年6月生效。

年內有更多地產發展商向物業買家直接提供按揭貸款，其按揭成數往往高於金管局對認可機構實施審慎要求下許可的水平。金管局密切留意有關發展，並定期與認可機構溝通，以評估銀行有否繼續有效管理對地產發展商的風險承擔。此外，土地註冊處應金管局要求，同意向認可機構提供電子提示服務。使用這項服務的認可機構，當有其他按揭文書就其承按的物業交付土地註冊處辦理註冊時，會收到該處發出的電子提示訊息。這項服務將有助應對按揭借款人未有事先獲得承按認可機構同意下，擅自以同一物業借取額外按揭貸款的情況。土地註冊處已於2017年第1季推出電子提示服務。

# 業務操作及科技風險的監管

與其他國際金融中心一樣，香港面對的網絡威脅與日俱增。金管局於2016年接到認可機構通報發現未經授權股票交易及試圖入侵其支付系統的個案，並隨即採取行動應對這些攻擊造成的風險。金管局發出電子銀行服務提示，提醒公眾慎防網上股票交易騙案，並建議公眾採取預防措施。金管局又向認可機構發出通告，就進一步加強網上銀行服務監控可採取的保安措施提供指引。有關試圖入侵銀行支付系統的個案，金管局在香港首次發現相關個案時已提醒認可機構留意這類騙案，並在警方協助下說明這類騙案的犯案手法，以及要求認可機構在加強支付操作的監控措施時須顧及有關手法。

為進一步提升銀行體系應對網絡風險的能力，金管局於2016年5月推出網絡防衛計劃。此計劃由三項支柱組成，即網絡防衛評估框架、專業培訓計劃及網絡風險資訊共享平台（詳見「香港的國際金融中心地位」一章「金融科技促進辦公室」部分）。金管局在12月向認可機構發出通告，列載網絡防衛評估框架的實施時間表。

金融科技在銀行業的應用於2016年長足發展，多間認可機構推出新的金融科技產品，其中個人小額支付服務、非接觸式流動支付及生物認證這幾個範疇的發展尤為顯著。金管局在9月推出「金融科技監管沙盒」，讓認可機構能在受控環境中就其金融科技項目先作試行，而無需完全符合金管局的監管規定。有關安排讓認可機構在正式推出金融科技服務前，可及早收集真實數據及用戶意見，以便作出適當修改。截至2016年底，共有6項使用金融科技監管沙盒的申請獲批，有關的新金融科技產品涉及生物認證、證券交易及用於按揭估值的區塊鏈。金管局又在11月上調無需雙重認證的網上銀行個人小額支付服務的交易上限至每個帳戶每日5,000港元，以應付日益增加的簡便個人支付服務需求。

2016年發生多宗與物業相關的騙案，當中涉及騙徒假扮業主，試圖藉申請按揭貸款或出售有關物業謀取利益。雖然這些騙案並不涉及認可機構，但金管局仍與警方及香港銀行公會（銀行公會）緊密合作，就偵測及防止這些騙案在銀行業內發生向認可機構提供指引。年內金管局出版兩期《操作事故通訊》，與業界分享從認可機構發生過的操作事故中汲取的教訓。金管局亦對認可機構的業務操作風險管理制度、詐騙管理方法、信託╱託管業務操作及防範違規或未經授權交易活動的風險管理及監控措施進行現場審查及專題評估。

# 財資業務及流動性風險的監管

2016年發生數宗重大政治事件，引致金融市場在年內多次大幅波動。與此同時，美國利率繼續緩慢地正常化，聯邦公開市場委員會於12月決定調高聯邦基金利率，是全球金融危機以來的第二次。為應對這些政治事件作好準備，金管局與境外監管機構繼續保持緊密聯繫，並評估事件對香港銀行體系的影響，以及要求銀行保持警覺並加強其風險管理以應對不利的市場發展。

在流動性風險管理方面，金管局進行額外的流動性壓力測試，以評估銀行體系應對可能發生的嚴峻壓力情境的能力，並對認可機構作出跟進，以加強其應對能力。金管局在2015年針對利率風險管理進行一輪現場審查後，再進行額外的現場審查，以評估認可機構的市場風險管理，並要求在監控方面存有不足的認可機構作出糾正。

# 打擊洗錢及恐怖分子資金籌集活動

金管局的風險為本打擊洗錢監管包括現場審查及非現場審查（包括就特定事件與認可機構進行的監管聯繫），主要針對洗錢及恐怖分子資金籌集風險較高的範疇。審查內容涵蓋認可機構對洗錢及恐怖分子資金籌集風險的評估、風險為本方法的落實情況，以及交易監察與制裁合規的制度和程序。金管局的專項監管人員在2016年共進行17次現場審查及30次非現場審查。

在政策發展方面，金管局優先處理某些行業及人士在開立銀行帳戶方面遇到困難的情況，並發出指引與「常見問題」，以釐清若干客戶盡職審查的規定，以及金管局就風險為本方法的監管期望。與此同時，金管局繼續與業內公會緊密合作，發出指引以協助認可機構處理某些範疇的風險，例如貿易相關的洗錢活動。

# Bank System Stability

Despite increased global market risks and turbulence, the Hong Kong banking system remained resilient in 2016. The HKMA strengthened the risk governance framework of its approved institutions and the effectiveness of their credit and liquidity risk management systems throughout the year. Given the increasing frequency of cyber attacks, the HKMA also enhanced cybersecurity risk management for approved institutions. To fulfill its goal of combating financial crimes, the HKMA continued to focus on monitoring measures to combat money laundering and terrorist financing, which remain key supervisory priorities. In terms of conduct, the HKMA took substantive actions to promote customer-centric culture and financial literacy, and addressed difficulties faced by overseas SMEs and start-ups in opening and maintaining bank accounts in Hong Kong. The HKMA also intensified supervision of approved institutions’ sales practices for investment and insurance products to further enhance customer protection.

On the policy front, the HKMA made significant progress in implementing international regulatory and accounting standards in Hong Kong; including the implementation of the Basel III liquidity standards, large exposure limits, International Financial Reporting Standard 9, and the resolution framework under the Banking (Resolution) Ordinance.

# 2016 Review

# Overview of Supervisory Work

In 2016, the HKMA conducted 188 off-site reviews covering a broad scope, including the CAMEL ratings, corporate governance, operational practices, and risk management of approved institutions. The HKMA strengthened its communication with the boards of directors of approved institutions to reinforce bank risk governance and corporate culture. Besides meetings with boards or their committees, it also held separate discussions with independent non-executive directors (INEDs) to exchange views on corporate culture and risk governance. The HKMA also held tripartite meetings with approved institutions and their external auditors. Moreover, it evaluated whether the approved institutions’ remuneration policies supported effective risk management.

Regarding capital adequacy, the HKMA reviewed the capital plans of approved institutions, including their capital targets for future years, to prepare for the full implementation of Basel III buffers by 2019. Recovery stress testing was also improved to reflect current macroeconomic conditions. The HKMA carefully assessed the recovery plans of major retail banks and provided recommendations for improvements.

Beyond off-site reviews, the HKMA continued thematic assessments combined with periodic on-site examinations, mainly targeting higher-risk areas. This approach enabled a more effective allocation of supervisory resources to address newly identified and significant risks faced by approved institutions. In 2016, a total of 377 on-site examinations and thematic assessments were carried out. The focus remained on credit risk management and monitoring, especially related to Mainland China-related business; another key area was the monitoring of anti-money laundering and counter-terrorist financing measures. The HKMA also increased on-site assessments for liquidity, operational risks, and cyber risks. During the year, a special review team conducted on-site examinations of approved institutions’ securities, investment products, insurance, and MPF-related businesses.

Table 1 summarizes the supervisory activities of the HKMA in 2016.

# Credit Risk Supervision

# Credit Growth and Asset Quality

Bank loans grew modestly in 2016, with total outstanding loans increasing by 6.5% over the year; in 2015, the growth was 3.5% (see Table 2). Since customer deposits increased at a faster rate than loans, the overall loans-to-deposits ratio declined from 70.1% at end-2015 to 68.4% at end-2016.

Table 2 Growth in Loans and Advances

Mainland China-related loans increased by 7% to HK$3,564 billion at the end of 2016 (see Table 3), including HK$545 billion of loans recorded by bank subsidiaries registered in Mainland China.

Asset quality in the banking sector remained sound in 2016. Although the specific classified loan ratio for retail banks rose slightly from 0.69% at the end of 2015 to 0.72% at the end of 2016, it still remained well below the long-term average of 2.4% since 2000. The overall classified loan ratio for the entire banking sector increased from 0.73% to 0.85% during the same period. The asset quality of Mainland China-related loans in 2016 was generally stable; for retail banks, the specific classified loan ratio increased slightly from 0.78% to 0.82%, and for the entire banking sector, the related ratio rose marginally from 0.77% to 0.80%.

The HKMA allocated substantial supervisory resources to ensure that approved institutions continued to adopt prudent credit approval standards and maintained effective loan classification and provisioning systems. It paid particular attention to the rising risk exposures of approved institutions to Mainland Chinese private enterprises, and the credit risks arising from their investments in debt securities aimed at increasing yields. Additionally, the HKMA conducted thematic assessments of credit risk management in approved institutions’ distribution of high-risk investment products.

# Property Mortgage Loans

The HKMA continued closely monitoring mortgage lending activities. Residential property prices, which had begun to decline in September 2015, increased again in March 2016, ending the year up 8%. The average loan-to-value (LTV) ratio for new residential mortgage loans decreased from 64% before the HKMA launched its first round of macroprudential measures in September 2009 to 51% in December 2016. Similarly, the average debt-service ratio for new residential mortgages fell from 41% in August 2010, when limits on debt-service ratios were first introduced, to 34% in December 2016 (see Figure 1).

Figure 1 Average LTV and DSR for New Residential Mortgage Loans
Limits on debt-service ratios introduced before the first round of macroprudential measures in September 2009

Under the seventh round of macroprudential measures launched in February 2015, approved institutions using the internal ratings-based approach to calculate credit risk capital requirements were required to extend the application of the 15% minimum risk-weighted capital requirement to the entire residential mortgage loan portfolio, from new loans onwards. This regulation took effect in June 2016.

During the year, more property developers offered mortgages directly to homebuyers, often with higher LTV ratios than permitted under prudent requirements imposed by the HKMA on approved institutions. The HKMA closely monitored these developments and regularly communicated with approved institutions to assess whether banks continued to effectively manage the associated risks. Additionally, the Lands Department, at the HKMA’s request, agreed to provide electronic notification services to approved institutions. When mortgaged properties receive registration entries from the Land Registry, approved institutions using this service will receive electronic alerts. This service helps address cases where mortgage borrowers take additional loans against the same property without prior approval from their approved institution. The Land Registry launched this electronic notification service in the first quarter of 2017.

# Supervision of Business Operations and Technology Risks

Similar to other global financial centers, Hong Kong faces increasing cyber threats. In 2016, the HKMA received reports from approved institutions indicating unauthorized stock trading and attempted intrusions into their payment systems, prompting immediate action to mitigate these risks. The HKMA issued alerts on electronic banking services to remind the public to beware of online stock trading scams and advised on preventive measures. It also issued notices to approved institutions offering guidance on enhancing cybersecurity for online banking services. The HKMA had previously warned about such scams when they first emerged in Hong Kong, detailing the tactics used with police assistance, and emphasized the importance of strengthening payment operation surveillance.

To further enhance the banking system’s cyber resilience, the HKMA launched a Cybersecurity Fortification Initiative (CFI) in May 2016. The program comprises three pillars: a cybersecurity risk assessment framework, professional training, and a cybersecurity risk information sharing platform (see “Hong Kong’s Status as an International Financial Center” Chapter “Fintech Facilitation Office”). In December, the HKMA issued a notice outlining the implementation timetable for the cybersecurity risk assessment framework.

The application of financial technology (Fintech) in banking grew rapidly in 2016, with many approved institutions introducing new Fintech products, especially in personal small-value payments, contactless mobile payments, and biometric authentication. In September, the HKMA launched the Fintech Supervisory Sandbox, allowing approved institutions to pilot their Fintech projects in a controlled environment without fully complying with existing regulations. This facility enables early collection of real transaction data and user feedback, allowing for necessary adjustments later. By the end of 2016, six applications to use the Fintech Supervisory Sandbox had been approved, involving biometric authentication, securities trading, and blockchain-based mortgage valuation. In November, the HKMA raised the transaction limit for online banking small-value payments without dual authentication to HK$5,000 per day per account, to meet rising demand for convenient personal payment services.

In 2016, multiple property-related scams surfaced, involving fraudsters impersonating owners to apply for mortgages or sell properties for illicit gain. Although these scams do not directly involve approved institutions, the HKMA worked closely with police and the Hong Kong Association of Banks to provide guidance on detecting and preventing such frauds within banks. During the year, the HKMA published two issues of the Operational Incidents Watch to share lessons learned from past operational incidents. The HKMA also conducted on-site inspections and thematic assessments of approved institutions’ operational risk management systems, fraud prevention measures, trustee/custodian operations, and measures to mitigate risks of unauthorized or rogue transactions.

# Treasury and Liquidity Risk Supervision

In 2016, several major political events led to significant volatility in financial markets. Meanwhile, U.S. interest rates continued to normalize gradually; in December, the Federal Open Market Committee raised the federal funds rate for the second time since the global financial crisis. To prepare for such political developments, the HKMA maintained close links with overseas regulators and assessed their potential impact on Hong Kong’s banking system, urging banks to remain vigilant and strengthen their risk management against adverse market conditions.

Regarding liquidity risk management, the HKMA conducted additional liquidity stress tests to evaluate the banking system’s resilience under severe stress scenarios, and followed up with approved institutions to enhance their preparedness. After a review of interest rate risk management through on-site examinations in 2015, further on-site reviews assessed market risk management, requiring institutions with weaknesses to address issues proactively.

# Combating Money Laundering and Terrorist Financing

The HKMA’s risk-based AML/CFT supervision, comprising on-site and off-site reviews (including regulatory contact on specific incidents), primarily targeted areas with higher risks of money laundering and terrorist financing. Reviews covered the assessment of AML/CFT risks, implementation of a risk-based approach, transaction monitoring, and sanctions compliance procedures. In 2016, the HKMA conducted 17 on-site inspections and 30 off-site reviews.

Policy-wise, the HKMA prioritized addressing difficulties encountered by certain industries and individuals in opening bank accounts, issuing guidance and answering Frequently Asked Questions to clarify customer due diligence requirements and supervisory expectations for a risk-based approach. It also continued working with industry associations to issue guidance on risks associated with trade-based money laundering.

# 香港的國際金融中心地位

香港維持其作為全球離岸人民幣業務樞紐的地位。去年的稅務修訂有助營造有利環境，吸引跨國公司在港設立企業財資中心。為發展香港成為基建融資中心與金融科技樞紐，金管局在年內成立基建融資促進辦公室及金融科技促進辦公室。年內金管局向儲值支付工具發行人批出13個牌照。香港穩健的財政表現及龐大的對外資產淨值，繼續獲得信貸評級機構確認，其中標準普爾維持對香港AAA的評級。

# 概覽

受到環球金融市場波動及人民幣匯率前景不確定性影響，2016年全球離岸人民幣業務有所放緩。儘管如此，香港維持其作為全球離岸人民幣業務樞紐的地位，處理全球約七成人民幣支付交易。深港股票市場交易互聯互通機制「深港通」於12月推出，標誌着內地資本帳開放的另一里程碑，並且是提升香港的國際金融中心地位的重要一步。金管局亦透過擴大對市場的人民幣流動性支援及推出措施增加人民幣市場流動性的透明度，強化金融基建。

金管局於7月成立基建融資促進辦公室(IFFO)，透過匯聚主要持份者促進基建發展，並發展香港成為基建融資中心。截至2017年1月底，已有超過60間機構加入IFFO成為合作夥伴。年內金管局亦成功推動法例修訂的通過，以消除稅務不對稱及提供稅務優惠，鼓勵跨國及內地公司在香港設立企業財資中心，為金融及專業服務行業帶來更多商機。在香港駐設業務的機構投資者數目亦逐漸增加，其中作為全球第三大主權基金的阿布扎比投資局於10月宣布在香港成立海外辦事處，是該機構唯一設於阿布扎比以外的辦事處。

國際貨幣基金組織（基金組織）在去年的第四條磋商討論中對我們致力鞏固香港作為國際金融中心的地位給予正面評價。年內金管局積極參與國際討論，致力推進全球與區內金融穩定。金管局亦與國際信貸評級機構保持緊密溝通，有關工作有助香港的信貸評級在2016年獲得主要信貸評級機構確認。

香港金融基建的安全有效運作與持續發展，對鞏固香港作為國際金融中心及全球離岸人民幣業務樞紐的競爭力發揮重要作用。處理銀行同業交易的4個即時支付結算(RTGS)系統及債務工具中央結算系統（CMU系統）在2016年達到100%的系統可供使用率，高於99.95%的目標水平。

金管局在2016年進一步加強香港的零售支付金融基建。年內根據2016年11月全面生效的《支付系統及儲值支付工具條例》（《支付條例》）批出總共13個儲值支付工具牌照。電子支票服務涵蓋範圍亦已擴展至香港和廣東省（包括深圳）之間的跨境支付。

為促進香港金融科技的發展，金管局於3月成立金融科技促進辦公室。年內實施的多項重要措施均取得理想進展。

金管局推出一系列措施加強銀行業軟實力，包括(i)推出提升董事專業能力計劃；(ii)訂立整體業界的銀行從業員專業資歷架構；及(iii)推行消費者教育計劃。

# 2016年回顧

# 離岸人民幣業務

2016年環球金融市場波動及人民幣匯率前景不確定性令全球離岸人民幣業務有所放緩。截至年底，香港人民幣客戶存款及存款證餘額合共為6,251億元人民幣，較上年減少38%（圖1）。年內離岸人民幣債券發行量降至528億元人民幣，經香港銀行處理的人民幣貿易結算額亦降至45,421億元人民幣。另一方面，香港銀行截至年底的人民幣貸款餘額為2,948億元人民幣，與上年相若（圖2）。人民幣RTGS系統的交易額維持於高位，於2016年平均每日處理的交易額為8,636億元人民幣。由此可見，儘管人民幣資金池有所縮減，但仍繼續支持大量人民幣金融中介活動在香港進行。根據環球銀行金融電信協會(SWIFT)統計數字，2016年香港處理約七成人民幣支付交易，足以證明香港作為全球離岸人民幣業務樞紐的地位。

圖1 人民幣客戶存款及存款證

圖2 人民幣融資活動

年內金管局與內地有關當局緊密合作爭取更大政策空間，推展香港人民幣業務。年內推出多項新措施，包括進一步加大內地銀行間債券市場及外匯市場對外開放，以及在12月推出「深港通」。因應跨境投資渠道及市場對流動性管理需求增加，金管局擴大人民幣流動資金安排。於10月，金管局將一級流動性提供行的數目由7間增加至9間，有關計劃的總額度亦由140億元人民幣增加至180億元人民幣。金管局人民幣流動資金安排使用情況的透明度亦提高，有助參加行更有效管理流動資金。

在3月公布的國家「十三五」規劃再次肯定香港作為全球離岸人民幣業務樞紐的地位，顯示中央政府支持香港進一步發展離岸人民幣業務。

# 內地與香港關於建立更緊密經貿關係的安排

# Hong Kong's Status as an International Financial Centre

Hong Kong maintains its position as a global offshore renminbi business hub. Last year's tax amendments helped create a favorable environment to attract multinational companies to establish corporate treasury centres in Hong Kong. To develop Hong Kong into an infrastructure financing hub and a fintech centre, the HKMA established the Infrastructure Financing Office and the Fintech Facilitation Office during the year. Within the same period, the HKMA issued 13 licences to stored value facilities licensees. Hong Kong’s robust fiscal performance and large net external assets continue to be confirmed by credit rating agencies, with Standard & Poor’s maintaining a AAA rating for Hong Kong.

# Overview

Influenced by volatility in the global financial markets and uncertainties over the renminbi exchange rate outlook, global offshore renminbi activities slowed down in 2016. Nonetheless, Hong Kong retained its status as a global offshore renminbi business hub, processing about 70% of the world’s renminbi payments. The Shenzhen-Hong Kong Stock Connect was launched in December, marking another milestone in Mainland China’s capital account liberalization and an important step in enhancing Hong Kong’s status as an international financial centre. The HKMA further increased renminbi liquidity transparency through expanding liquidity support to the market and introducing measures to strengthen the liquidity and development of the renminbi market infrastructure.

In July, the HKMA established the Infrastructure Financing Office (IFFO) to gather major stakeholders to promote infrastructure development and develop Hong Kong into an infrastructure financing centre. As of the end of January 2017, over 60 institutions had joined IFFO as partners, including multilateral financial institutions, development banks, public sector investors, private sector investors, asset management companies, banks, insurance companies, infrastructure project developers and operators, professional service firms, and international trade associations (Table 1).

Since its establishment, IFFO has made good progress. To enhance skills and knowledge, in October, IFFO and the International Finance Corporation (IFC) under the World Bank Group organised an executive workshop on “Private Sector Participation in Infrastructure Investment in Emerging Markets,” which received very positive feedback from participants and helped deepen their understanding and networks. In November, IFFO held a high-level seminar, inviting Mr. Jin Liqun, President of the Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank, to share experience in infrastructure project planning, operation, and management. In July, IFFO signed Memorandums of Understanding (MOUs) with IFC and the Global Infrastructure Facility to establish cooperation frameworks. In December, MOUs were also signed with the China Development Bank and the Export-Import Bank of China, promoting infrastructure project financing through the IFFO platform. These activities help strengthen Hong Kong’s position and reputation as an infrastructure financing hub.

Mr. Norman Chan, Chief Executive of the HKMA (front row, far left), and other guests attended the launch ceremony of IFFO and toasted to success.

The HKMA’s proactive measures have seen over 60 institutions from Mainland China, Hong Kong, and overseas partner with IFFO by January 2017, including many multilateral finance institutions, development banks, public and private investors, asset managers, banks, insurance companies, and infrastructure project developers and operators. IFFO’s efforts include forging strategic partnerships, such as signing MOUs with IFC and the Global Infrastructure Facility to facilitate efficient infrastructure investment and financing in the region (Figures 1 & 2).

# Corporate Treasury Centres

To attract more multinational companies to establish corporate treasury centres in Hong Kong, the HKMA and government authorities have worked together to create a tax environment conducive to such development. Specifically, the 《Taxation (Amendment) (No. 2) Ordinance 2016》 was enacted in June, allowing enterprises that meet specified criteria to deduct interest expenses on internal group financing when calculating profits tax, and to enjoy a 50% concession on profits derived from qualifying treasury business, reducing the profits tax rate to 8.25%. Table 2 summarizes key aspects of the 《Amendment》.

Apart from legislative efforts, the HKMA actively promotes the advantages of establishing corporate treasury centres in Hong Kong to multinational and Mainland Chinese companies. By the end of the year, the HKMA had engaged nearly 400 companies, financial institutions, and industry associations. In November, the HKMA signed an MOU with the Hong Kong Chinese Enterprises Association to assist Chinese enterprises in Hong Kong to better understand and utilize the platform for their corporate treasury activities.

# Promoting Asset Management Business

The HKMA continues to promote Hong Kong as a centre for asset management. According to the Securities and Futures Commission (SFC), as of the end of 2016, there were approximately 1,300 licensed asset management firms, an increase of nearly 15% year-on-year. The Asia Private Equity Journal reported that the number of private equity firms in Hong Kong (including SFC-licensed and unlicensed firms) increased by 4.6% to 431 in 2016. Nearly 70 of the world’s top 100 asset management firms, and most among China’s top 20 mutual fund managers, have established operations or affiliated firms in Hong Kong. The number of institutional investors based in Hong Kong also steadily increased. Notably, the Abu Dhabi Investment Authority (ADIA), as the world’s third-largest sovereign fund, announced in October the establishment of an overseas office in Hong Kong, the only one outside Abu Dhabi.

The International Monetary Fund (IMF), in its recent Article IV Consultation discussions, recognized Hong Kong’s efforts in consolidating its status as an international financial centre. Throughout the year, the HKMA actively participated in international discussions, promoting financial stability both globally and regionally. The HKMA also maintained close communication with major credit rating agencies, which contributed to Hong Kong’s credit ratings being reaffirmed by major agencies in 2016.

The robust and secure operation and continuous development of Hong Kong’s financial infrastructure are vital to strengthening Hong Kong’s competitiveness as an international financial centre and as a global offshore renminbi business hub. In 2016, the four real-time gross settlement (RTGS) systems and the Central Moneymarkets Unit (CMU) system achieved 100% system availability, exceeding the target level of 99.95%.

The HKMA further strengthened Hong Kong’s retail payment infrastructure in 2016. Under the comprehensive Payment System and Stored Value Facilities (SVF) Ordinance enacted in November 2016, a total of 13 licences for stored value facilities were issued within the year. The scope of electronic check services has also been expanded to include cross-border payments between Hong Kong and Guangdong (including Shenzhen).

To promote fintech development in Hong Kong, the HKMA established the Fintech Facilitation Office in March. Many important initiatives introduced during the year have achieved promising progress.

The HKMA launched a series of measures to enhance the resilience of the banking industry, including (i) launching a director training programme to improve board directors’ professional capabilities; (ii) establishing a comprehensive bank professional qualification framework; and (iii) implementing a consumer education programme.

# 2016 Review

# Offshore Renminbi Activities

In 2016, global financial market volatility and uncertainties over the renminbi exchange rate outlook led to a slowdown in worldwide offshore renminbi activities. By year-end, Hong Kong’s renminbi customer deposits and certificates of deposit amounted to RMB 625.1 billion, a 38% decrease from the previous year (Figure 1). Offshore renminbi bond issuance declined to RMB 52.8 billion, and renminbi trade settlement processed through Hong Kong banks decreased to RMB 4,542.1 billion. Meanwhile, as of year-end, the renminbi loan balance in Hong Kong banks was RMB 294.8 billion, roughly unchanged from the previous year (Figure 2). Renminbi RTGS transaction volume remained high, averaging RMB 863.6 billion daily in 2016. Despite a reduction in the renminbi liquidity pool, the continued large-scale renminbi financial intermediation activities in Hong Kong demonstrate its essential role. According to SWIFT, in 2016, Hong Kong processed about 70% of the world’s renminbi payments, underscoring its status as a global offshore renminbi business hub.

Throughout the year, the HKMA worked closely with Mainland authorities to secure greater policy space and promote Hong Kong’s renminbi business. Several new measures were introduced, including further opening Mainland China’s interbank bond market and foreign exchange market, and the December launch of the “Shenzhen-Hong Kong Stock Connect.” In response to increased cross-border investment channels and market liquidity management needs, the HKMA expanded renminbi liquidity arrangements. In October, the number of primary liquidity providers was increased from 7 to 9, with total quotas rising from RMB 14 billion to RMB 18 billion. Transparency in the use of renminbi liquidity arrangements was also enhanced, helping participants manage liquidity more effectively.

The “13th Five-Year Plan” announced by the central government in March reaffirmed Hong Kong’s role as a global offshore renminbi business hub, indicating strong support from the central authorities for Hong Kong’s further development of offshore renminbi activities.

Simultaneously, the HKMA continued strengthening cooperation with other economies to develop offshore renminbi business. The HKMA actively participated in various industry and private sector activities to promote Hong Kong as the global offshore renminbi hub and a key platform for Mainland China’s “Going Global” strategy, including involvement in industry associations and overseas events in Mainland China, Germany, Kazakhstan, and the United Kingdom.

Under the framework of the “Mainland and Hong Kong Closer Economic and Trade Relationship Arrangement,” a new agreement to further liberalize service trade between Mainland China and Hong Kong was signed in 2015. The HKMA continues to monitor the implementation of current measures and collaborates with government authorities to explore further market openings and facilitation measures for Hong Kong’s financial industry.

The HKMA continues to promote Hong Kong as an asset management centre. # Introducing Open-ended Fund Company Structure

To attract funds to register in Hong Kong, the HKMA continues working with the government and industry to create a more favourable tax and regulatory environment. # Islamic Finance

The HKMA remains committed to increasing awareness and understanding of Islamic finance, including organising and participating in Islamic finance seminars and conferences, sharing experiences in issuing sukuk, and encouraging market participants to use Hong Kong’s platform.
